Under the hereditary Caesars—for the Flavian dynasty had been even more strictly hereditary than the Claudian-the Senate had indeed been the second power in the State, but it had been chronically out of harmony with the first, and therefore had been by various means neutralised and re- pressed. A statesman who wished the Senate to be supreme, or even to manifest an independent activity, found himself permanently condemned to ‘the cold shade of opposition,’ and this, in the Roman climate, was a situation very danger- ous to health and life. An old man, of honourable birth and character, had been made the organ of the Senate for directing the armies of the State 3 the only consequence was, that the armies had declined to be directed by the Senate at all.
